cards.back: A push or pull that can change an object's motion. Measured in Newtons (N). Example: Gravity pulling objects toward Earth.
cards.subject: Physics - Mechanics

cards.back: The amount of matter in an object. Measured in kilograms (kg). Mass is constant regardless of location.
cards.subject: Physics - Mechanics

cards.back: The force of gravity acting on an object's mass. Weight = mass × gravitational acceleration (W = mg).
cards.subject: Physics - Mechanics

cards.back: The rate of change of velocity with time. Measured in meters per second squared (m/s²).
cards.subject: Physics - Mechanics

cards.back: The product of an object's mass and velocity (p = mv). Momentum is conserved in closed systems.
cards.subject: Physics - Mechanics

cards.back: The ability to do work. Types include kinetic (motion), potential (position), and thermal (heat) energy.
cards.subject: Physics - Mechanics

cards.back: The rate at which work is done or energy is transferred. Measured in Watts (W). Power = Work/Time.
cards.subject: Physics - Mechanics

cards.back: Force applied over a distance. Work = Force × Distance × cos(θ). Measured in Joules (J).
cards.subject: Physics - Mechanics

cards.back: The ratio of useful work output to total energy input. Efficiency = (Useful Output/Total Input) × 100%.
cards.subject: Physics - Mechanics

cards.front: Define and explain: Conservation of Energy
cards.back: Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed from one form to another.
cards.subject: Physics - Mechanics

cards.back: A measure of the average kinetic energy of particles in a substance. Measured in Kelvin (K) or Celsius (°C).
cards.subject: Physics - Thermodynamics

cards.back: Energy transferred between objects due to temperature difference. Heat flows from hot to cold objects.
cards.subject: Physics - Thermodynamics

cards.back: The total energy of all particles in a system, including kinetic and potential energy.
cards.subject: Physics - Thermodynamics

cards.back: A measure of disorder or randomness in a system. Entropy always increases in isolated systems.
cards.subject: Physics - Thermodynamics

cards.front: What is First Law of Thermodynamics?
cards.back: Energy cannot be created or destroyed. The change in internal energy equals heat added minus work done.
cards.subject: Physics - Thermodynamics

cards.front: What is Second Law of Thermodynamics?
cards.back: Heat cannot spontaneously flow from a colder body to a hotter body. Entropy increases over time.
cards.subject: Physics - Thermodynamics

cards.back: The amount of heat required to raise the temperature of a substance by 1°C. Units: J/°C or J/K.
cards.subject: Physics - Thermodynamics

cards.back: The heat capacity per unit mass of a substance. Units: J/kg°C or J/kgK.
cards.subject: Physics - Thermodynamics

cards.back: The heat required to change the phase of a substance (solid to liquid, liquid to gas) without changing temperature.
cards.subject: Physics - Thermodynamics

cards.back: The tendency of matter to change volume in response to temperature changes. Most substances expand when heated.
cards.subject: Physics - Thermodynamics

cards.back: A disturbance that transfers energy through a medium or space without transferring matter.
cards.subject: Physics - Waves

cards.back: The maximum displacement of a wave from its equilibrium position. Determines wave intensity.
cards.subject: Physics - Waves

cards.back: The distance between two consecutive points in phase on a wave (e.g., crest to crest).
cards.subject: Physics - Waves

cards.back: The number of complete wave cycles per second. Measured in Hertz (Hz).
cards.subject: Physics - Waves

cards.back: The time for one complete wave cycle. Period = 1/Frequency.
cards.subject: Physics - Waves

cards.front: Explain the concept of Wave Speed
cards.back: The speed at which a wave travels through a medium. Wave Speed = Frequency × Wavelength.
cards.subject: Physics - Waves

cards.front: Explain the concept of Transverse Wave
cards.back: A wave where particles vibrate perpendicular to the direction of wave travel (e.g., light waves).
cards.subject: Physics - Waves

cards.front: Explain the concept of Longitudinal Wave
cards.back: A wave where particles vibrate parallel to the direction of wave travel (e.g., sound waves).
cards.subject: Physics - Waves

cards.back: The interaction of two or more waves. Constructive interference increases amplitude; destructive decreases it.
cards.subject: Physics - Waves

cards.back: The phenomenon where a system vibrates at maximum amplitude at its natural frequency.
cards.subject: Physics - Waves

cards.back: A fundamental property of matter. Like charges repel; opposite charges attract. Measured in Coulombs (C).
cards.subject: Physics - Electricity

cards.back: A region around a charged object where other charges experience electric force. Field lines show direction.
cards.subject: Physics - Electricity

cards.back: The electric potential energy per unit charge at a point. Measured in Volts (V).
cards.subject: Physics - Electricity

cards.back: The rate of flow of electric charge. Current = Charge/Time. Measured in Amperes (A).
cards.subject: Physics - Electricity

cards.back: The difference in electric potential between two points. Voltage = Work/Charge. Measured in Volts (V).
cards.subject: Physics - Electricity

cards.back: The opposition to electric current flow. Resistance = Voltage/Current. Measured in Ohms (Ω).
cards.subject: Physics - Electricity

cards.back: The rate at which electrical energy is transferred. Power = Voltage × Current. Measured in Watts (W).
cards.subject: Physics - Electricity

cards.back: The ability of a capacitor to store electric charge. Capacitance = Charge/Voltage. Measured in Farads (F).
cards.subject: Physics - Electricity

cards.back: The ability of an inductor to store energy in a magnetic field. Measured in Henries (H).
cards.subject: Physics - Electricity

cards.back: The relationship between voltage, current, and resistance: V = IR (Voltage = Current × Resistance).
cards.subject: Physics - Electricity

cards.back: The emission of electrons from a metal surface when light shines on it. Supports particle nature of light.
cards.subject: Physics - Modern Physics

cards.back: The concept that light and matter exhibit both wave-like and particle-like properties.
cards.subject: Physics - Modern Physics

cards.back: The branch of physics that describes the behavior of matter and energy at atomic and subatomic scales.
cards.subject: Physics - Modern Physics

cards.back: Einstein's theory that space and time are interconnected, and that the speed of light is constant for all observers.
cards.subject: Physics - Modern Physics

cards.back: The splitting of a heavy nucleus into smaller nuclei, releasing energy. Used in nuclear power plants.
cards.subject: Physics - Modern Physics

cards.back: The combining of light nuclei to form heavier nuclei, releasing energy. Powers the Sun and stars.
cards.subject: Physics - Modern Physics

cards.back: The spontaneous emission of radiation from unstable atomic nuclei. Types: alpha, beta, gamma decay.
cards.subject: Physics - Modern Physics

cards.back: The time required for half of a radioactive substance to decay. Each isotope has a unique half-life.
cards.subject: Physics - Modern Physics

cards.back: Einstein's famous equation E = mc², showing that mass and energy are interchangeable.
cards.subject: Physics - Modern Physics

cards.back: Hypothetical matter that doesn't emit light but exerts gravitational force. Comprises most of the universe's mass.
cards.subject: Physics - Modern Physics

cards.front: What is the formula for Kinetic Energy?
cards.back: KE = ½mv² (Kinetic Energy = ½ × mass × velocity²)
cards.subject: Physics - Formulas

cards.front: What is the formula for Gravitational Potential Energy?
cards.back: GPE = mgh (GPE = mass × gravitational acceleration × height)
cards.subject: Physics - Formulas

cards.front: What is the formula for Power?
cards.back: P = W/t (Power = Work/Time)
cards.subject: Physics - Formulas

cards.front: What is the formula for Density?
cards.back: ρ = m/V (Density = mass/volume)
cards.subject: Physics - Formulas

cards.front: What is the formula for Pressure?
cards.back: P = F/A (Pressure = Force/Area)
cards.subject: Physics - Formulas

cards.front: What is the formula for Wave Speed?
cards.back: v = fλ (Wave Speed = frequency × wavelength)
cards.subject: Physics - Formulas

cards.front: What is the formula for Ohm's Law?
cards.back: V = IR (Voltage = Current × Resistance)
cards.subject: Physics - Formulas

cards.front: What is the formula for Work?
cards.back: W = Fd cos(θ) (Work = Force × distance × cos(angle))
cards.subject: Physics - Formulas

cards.front: What is the formula for Momentum?
cards.back: p = mv (Momentum = mass × velocity)
cards.subject: Physics - Formulas

cards.front: What is the formula for Acceleration?
cards.back: a = (v-u)/t (Acceleration = change in velocity/time)
cards.subject: Physics - Formulas
